author: Europa Press
title: Puigdemont celebra el regreso de los huidos Rovira, Wagensberg y Serra: "Se acaba una injusticia"
text:
BARCELONA, 12 Jul. (EUROPA PRESS) -
El expresidente de la Generalitat Carles Puigdemont ha dado celebrado el regreso desde Suiza de la secretaria general de ERC, Marta Rovira; el diputado de ERC en el Parlament Ruben Wagensberg; el vicepresidente de Òmnium, Oleguer Serra; al periodista de 'La Directa' Jesús Rodríguez y al activista Josep Campmajó: "Se acaba una injusticia".
En un apunte en 'X' recogido por Europa Press, el también candidato de Junts a presidir la Generalitat ha dicho que "con exiliados, encarcelados y perseguidos no puede hacerse política en igualdad de condiciones", y que mientras eso dure no existirá ninguna normalidad.
Ha reivindicado que el regreso de Rovira, Wagensberg, Serra, Rodríguez y Campmajó, "perseguidos por la gran farsa judicial que ha sido el caso 'Tsunami", es una gran alegría, si bien ha advertido de que aún se está lejos de la normalidad política.
"Todavía estamos lejos de tener las condiciones que nos permitan hacer política con la normalidad a la que tenemos derecho, no sólo personalmente, sino sobre todo como pueblo", ha remarcado Puigdemont.
También ha deseado a los cinco que puedan recuperar estos años y meses que considera que les han sido robados, y les ha emplazado a volver al trabajo lo antes posible, ya que "hay mucho pendiente".
Leer más acerca de: Suiza ERC Carles Puigdemont Marta Rovira Òmnium Cultural

author: Mic2000
title: In late May, after an OTA session, Detroit Lions second year quarterback Hendon Hooker, a former Tennessee Vols standout, was pointed out as a player that "struggled". - Pride Of Detroit
text: [Former Vols QB Hendon Hooker provided an important reminder for all NFL fans as training camps get underway](https://www.msn.com/en-us/sports/nfl/former-vols-qb-hendon-hooker-provided-an-important-reminder-for-all-nfl-fans-as-training-camps-get-underway/ar-BB1qCubg?ocid=socialshare) In late May, after an OTA session, Detroit Lions second year quarterback Hendon Hooker, a former Tennessee Vols standout, [was pointed out as a player]that "struggled". Those reports led to some suggestions that Hooker might not be ready to step up and play the role of the No. 2 quarterback in Detroit. n late May, after an OTA session, Detroit Lions second year quarterback Hendon Hooker, a former Tennessee Vols standout, [was pointed out as a player]that "struggled". Those reports led to some suggestions that Hooker might not be ready to step up and play the role of the No. 2 quarterback in Detroit. Two months later and the tone coming out of Detroit about Hooker is much different. The former Tennessee standout [reportedly "shined" at Lions training camp]on Wednesday. "I was just super excited. Once I really calmed down, it was just getting back to regular schedule, and that’s just playing catch with the guys," [said Hooker to Lions On SI]. "I thought it was great after that first team set. I thought I had a great day today." "Once I calmed down, I had some jitters the first reps in team today. Once I calmed down and got my rhythm, I felt good," added Hooker. After that rough OTA in May, the narrative surrounding Hooker was that he was behind schedule and that he might not be able to be counted on as the No. 2 quarterback for the Lions in 2024. But that was always an unfair narrative. Basing anything on an OTA practice in May -- especially in regards to a player like Hooker who missed the majority of his rookie season while recovering from a torn ACL -- is absolutely absurd. Hooker's solid day on Wednesday, which quickly tipped the narrative back in his favor, is a big reminder that it's not wise to make any grand conclusions about a player during OTAs/minicamps. Development for a quarterback isn't linear and it isn't the same for every player. There are a wild variance of situations that each quarterback is facing in the NFL. When it comes to Hooker, he hasn't played meaningful football since November, 2022 (when he tore his ACL in a loss against the South Carolina Gamecocks). Expecting him to be peak Hendon Hooker in an OTA in May isn't reasonable. And anyway, those OTA sessions are a time when players are trying to find their rhythm, find what works, etc. It's not the time of year when they're getting "dialed in" for the regular season.The offseason is a fun time of year for NFL fans. There's room for speculation and everyone feels like they have a reason to be optimistic. But players aren't a finished product in the spring/summer. Hendon Hooker's great day on Wednesday is a reminder of how quick the narrative can change. Which is why forming a negative narrative after a couple of hours of practice is never a smart approach. yep, I didn't buy what was being sold about Hooker losing to Sudfeld. Sure, it would make some fans happy because they dont want competition for Goff. That guy has had no competition his entire career. Hooker, on the other hand, has never had a job handed to him. There was a rather dim narrative by some that if Hooker struggled in his first OTAs and minicamp, then he's a bust and suddenly, Sudfeld is going to the backup. That's a joke. It's real funny, that all the talk was on Hooker's struggles while Goff was struggling too. Goff had a 3 INT day, more than Hooker despite his struggles. It's not unusual for any player to struggle in the same circumstances. Hooker had a good day. His job is to stack them and be ready when the pads come on, that's a whole new level. Still, when we fans finally see him, I expect him to show awesome arm talent and mobility.

author: Elisa García Faya
title: El lado malo del 'clean look': por qué este peinado puede dañar tu cabello según los expertos
text:
¿Sabías que abusar del clean look y de las coletas y moños pulidos podría estar dañando la salud de tu pelo? ¡Sigue leyendo y te contamos cómo puedes evitarlo! No cabe duda de que el clean look ha sido una de las modas más virales de 2024. Como su nombre indica, es una tendencia de belleza que persigue acabados limpios y depurados. Pero, ¿cuál es el riesgo de abusar de ellos?
Si te haces constantemente peinados y coletas tirantes puedes sufrir lo que los expertos llaman alopecia por tracción. Rosi Fernández, directora del salón Ananda Ferdí, asegura que las coletas, trenzas y otros peinados que requieren tirar del cabello hacia atrás ejercen una tensión considerable sobre los folículos, lo que puede acabar en dolor. "Estos peinados también pueden contribuir a la alopecia por tracción si se mantienen durante periodos prolongados", confirma. Esto, a su vez, provoca que el pelo se quiebre y se acabe perdiendo.
El doctor Carlos Portinha, director médico del Grupo Insparya, asegura que "la alopecia por tracción, muy frecuente entre las mujeres, es común en las personas que usan peinados tirantes o apretados". "Es recomendable evitarlos e incluir en nuestra rutina productos específicos para cada tipo de cabello", explica el doctor, quien además insiste en la importancia de usar protectores térmicos si se van a usar herramientas de calor.
Productos "peligrosos"
El riesgo de sufrir alopecia por tracción se intensifica con el uso de fijadores, que acumulan mucho residuo en el cuero cabelludo. Así lo confirma la doctora Carmen Orozco, de Hospital Capilar. "Si no se retiran adecuadamente, pueden obstruir los poros y debilitar la fibra capilar", nos dice. "Es más, algunos fijadores contienen alcoholes que pueden resecar el cabello, lo que puede llevar a la fragilidad y caída", agrega.
Desde DS Laboratories recomiendan evitar estos productos porque dejan el cabello rígido y, al estar en este estado, es más frágil y propenso a quebrarse al tocarlo o peinarlo. Recomiendan "optar por fijadores de sujeción suave o flexible, que incluyen ingredientes acondicionadores y fortalecedores, como el ácido glicólico, que ayuda a dar fuerza a la fibra capilar y reduce el encrespamiento".
Tres alternativas al 'clean look'
No hay nada de malo en querer lucir de vez en cuando el clean look, sin embargo, es importante no caer en su abuso y, quizás, recurrir a él solo para ocasiones especiales. Igualmente, para nuestro día a día, podemos optar por opciones más seguras para nuestro cuero cabelludo y que nos harán lucir de igual modo una estética limpia y elegante. Desde la firma de champú en seco Batiste te ofrecen tres alternativas al clean look que evitarán los riesgos para tu cabello.
La más cómoda: ondas estilo 'messy hair'
El messy hair es la opción ideal que te permitirá evitar cualquier bad hair day. En este caso, las ondas con aire desenfadado, que dejan atrás los peinados rígidos y tirantes, son una opción excelente. Además de ofrecer naturalidad, las ondas le dan un toque chic al look.
Para realizarlas tan solo tendrás que desenredar bien tu cabello y echar mano de tu plancha. Aplica el producto protector de calor, seguidamente ve cogiendo mechones no muy gruesos y sujeta la plancha cerrada antes de girarla sobre sí misma dando media vuelta. Después desliza la plancha hasta las puntas. Para un resultado más natural, cuando se haya enfriado el cabello, puedes pasarte el cepillo de pelo y aplicarte Batiste Heavenly Volume que le aportará ese toque de volumen.
Elegante a la par que cómodo: semirrecogido
Si queremos optar por retirar el cabello de nuestro rostro, pero, a la vez, lucir una melena cuidada, los semirrecogidos son la opción que buscas.
Para recoger la parte superior del cabello y retirarlo del rostro tan solo tendrás que ayudarte de un peine. Una vez recogido, realiza una pequeña coleta y péinalo hacia atrás.
El clásico que no falla: un moño fijado por una pinza
Si hay un peinado que ha vuelto con más fuerza que nunca es el clásico moño fijado por una pinza. Fácil y cómodo, este recogido sirve tanto para una cita informal como para un evento más elegante y es que todo dependerá del accesorio con el que lo acompañemos.
Para realizarlo, en primer lugar peina la raya del cabello en el medio. Después, texturiza la melena. En este caso puedes ayudarte de un spray de styling o de un champú en seco, que le aportará textura y más volumen en tan solo unos segundos. A continuación, pasa un cepillo de cerdas naturales para llevar todo el cabello hasta la zona de la nuca. Recógelo con las manos y, en lugar de recoger con una goma, hazlo con una pinza.
Como ves, existen variadas opciones de peinados con los que lucir igual de espectacular que con el clean look. Aunque no tienes por qué decir adiós a este peinado para siempre, ¿qué tal cambiar de vez en cuando?

author: Outdoors Columnist - Unlimited Digital Access
title: How a cold snap can protect New York state ecosystems from invaders
text: Mild winters have hidden cost: How a cold snap can help protect ecosystems from invaders Native wildlife thrives in the wintertime, but that's not always true for invasive species. Cold weather may keep some invaders at bay. It’s not really news to anyone that pays attention to the outdoors that this winter has been incredibly mild so far, save for [this week's snow and wind storm](/story/news/2024/01/10/top-wind-gust-speeds-from-ny-storm/72173565007/). Actually, December was about the warmest on record in our area of Western New York, according to NOAA. While many, if not most folks are happy with this current lack of snow and cold, there are some ecological reasons to not be so joyful over these relatively mild climes and times. It is not just skiers, snowmobilers, and ice fishers, the wintertime recreationists, who bemoan our watered-down winter. Yes, our heating bills are lower too. And we haven’t had to shovel the walk. I agree, cold weather, a regular old-fashioned stretch of frigid temps, may be a bit challenging and uncomfortable to us, as well as to our native birds and animals. But it’s a real bane to those southern invasive species that have been making so many devastating inroads into our environment. Our familiar northern species of flora and fauna adapt well and sustain through the coldest snaps, but those hitchhikers, freeloaders, and windborne migrants whose genesis is from the South, or especially the Subtropics, die when the temps near zero degrees Fahrenheit. With the apparent warming trend of the last 30 years or so, we are hearing of and experiencing more and more of the damage done by invasive critters coming into our neck-of-the-woods. Plants, fish, mollusks, insects and molds are just some of the more headline-grabbing new invasive life forms. New York State in 2008 created the Invasive Species Council and Advisory Board, listing many of the species threatening our native plants, including Giant hogweed, Japanese barberry, Japanese knotweed, Purple loosestrife, and even Norway maple, all as threats. These new species often choke out our native plants and take over their ecological niches. Many thrive here because they find few native threats. Researchers have imported their natural enemies and released them in an effort to slow up their advance with mixed success. And the process of importing the invasive species’ enemies can be problematical because we are introducing another species that may out-compete a native down the road. Take the case of Purple loosestrife, a European garden flower that is choking our swamps and wetlands. Two species of an imported beetle are used, one attacks the flower, the other the roots. But who can say what kind of future effect the beetles will have? Invasive insects are devastating certain tree species such as the Hemlock Wooly Algid with its lethal effect on stands of our hemlock trees. The Emerald Ash borer is particularly devastating to stands of ash trees. Others are the Spongy moth (formerly called the Gypsy moth) and the Asian Longhorn beetle. The former is a threat to oak trees, the latter to many hardwood trees. Aquatic life forms, such as the Round Goby and the Zebra mussel, have wreaked havoc in the Great Lakes and other lake waters. And the threat of the Northern Snakehead and the jumping Asian Silver carp are knocking on the door in nearby states. Molds and spores that are invading our environment are particularly insidious. Topping that list may be Phytophythora infestans, popularly known as "Late Blight." Those of us who like to grow a few tomatoes may have been totally bummed out when we had our first encounter with this noxious fungal pest. We certainly are not alone. Its presence has been called a major factor in the great Irish potato famine in the middle of 19th century. One can only hope that by midwinter we’ll experience a stretch of Arctic cold that will have some effect on slowing down the attack of these and many other invasive species that find the subzero temps a challenge. More: [Whitetail bachelor groups are reforming with end of hunting season. How bucks spend winter](/story/sports/outdoors/2024/01/05/how-whitetail-bucks-bachelor-groups-spend-winter-after-surviving-hunting-season/72082443007/) Our native species have unique ways to deal with the cold, and of course thrive better when the competition is diminished. From the tiny ubiquitous chickadee that weighs no more than a quarter, to our whitetail deer that average around 150 pounds, nature has built in natural responses to the cold that get them through. Chickadees winter in hollow spaces in trees. Other wintering birds such as Brown creepers, Kinglets, Nuthatches and Sparrows will actually cluster together in a hollow tree to create a larger and more efficient thermal unit. They find a way to deal with the coldest stretches in winter. But invasive species, whether in the form of insects or plants or others have traditionally been beaten back by mid-winter Arctic fronts, now so few and far between. -- Oak Duke writes a weekly column.

author: ANI
title: Delhi registers warmest October month since 1951
text: October 2024 becomes the warmest October after 1951 in terms of both Maximum and Minimum temperatures in Safdarjung, New Delhi, the India Meteorological Department (IMD) said on Friday. According to the IMD, this month has recorded an average maximum temperature of 35.1 degrees Celsius and a minimum of 21.2 degrees Celsius over Safdarjung respectively. In 1907, the maximum temperature was 35.5 degrees Celsius, in 1930 maximum temperature was 35.0 degrees Celsius, in 1938 it recorded 35.0 degrees Celsius, in 1941 it recorded 35.8 degrees Celsius, in 1951 it recorded 36.2 degrees Celsius respectively. Delhi recorded a jump in pollution levels and a smoky haze returned on Friday morning after residents flouted the ban on firecrackers on Diwali night.Most areas in the capital recorded an Air Quality Index (AQI) over 350, raising health concerns for residents.114758596Cyclist Stephen, passing through India Gate where the AQI stood around 317 post-Diwali, said, Because of the pollution, terrible things are happening. The pollution came on very suddenly this time. Just a few days ago, there was nothing, and now my brother has fallen sick. I used to come here to cycle with my brother, but he has been severely affected by the pollution lately. And today, the pollution is extreme. At around 7:00 am, Anand Vihar recorded an AQI of 395, Aya Nagar stood at 352, Jahangirpuri at 390, and Dwarka reached 376. All these areas reported 'very poor' air quality levels, posing significant health risks.114647863The pollution issue wasn't limited to Delhi; several other cities across India, including metropolises like Chennai and Mumbai, reported similar conditions, with smog and poor air quality affecting large areas.The CPCB data shows significant pollution levels, especially after Diwali celebrations, raising concerns about air quality and potential health impacts nationwide. (ANI)
